columns.text: In this problem, we will evaluate the short-term financial plan of the given firm and determine whether the plan gives a net gain or a net loss.

A short-term financial plan, as the name suggests, allows the planning on how to solve the immediate problems of the company and develop a high net present value. As mentioned earlier in the chapter, the net present value of a company determines the difference between their current assets and liabilities which also measures their short-term financial health.

**a.)** In the short-term financial plan presented in the problem, we can see that there is a projected deficit in Quarters 2, 3, and 4. This can be seen since there is still a positive short-term debt at the end of the quarters. 

On the other hand, Quarter 1 has a surplus since the short-term debt at the end of this quarter is equal to zero.

**b.)** A decrease in minimum cash balance increases the value of cumulative surplus. These two values are inversely proportional to each other which means an increase in one will lower the other, and vice versa. 

Since the cumulative surplus increases, then the overall surplus will also increase.

In the case of this firm, since Quarters 2, 3, and 4 are on a deficit, decreasing the minimum cash balance will also decrease this deficit. On the other hand, the surplus in Quarter 1 will increase with this change.
